questions.text: A 45-year old presents for a routine gynecological checkup. She is having regular cycles with normal flow and mild dysmenorrhea on the 1 st day. She is a non-smoker and has no history of hypertension or diabetes. Her last pap smear was 2 years back which was reported to be normal. An ultrasound shows the presence of a 4 x 4 cm intramural fibroid with a sub-serosal component. She is very anxious and seeks your opinion on what should be done.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Review ultrasound after 1 year

Explanation:

  • • This is an asymptomatic fibroid Asymptomatic fibroids (irrespective of size) do not require treatment and just need an annual evaluation. Symptomatic fibroids can be managed medically/ surgically/ non invasive techniques based on several factors like the age of the patient, the size and number of fibroids and the location of fibroid
  • • This is an asymptomatic fibroid
  • • Asymptomatic fibroids (irrespective of size) do not require treatment and just need an annual evaluation.
  • • Symptomatic fibroids can be managed medically/ surgically/ non invasive techniques based on several factors like the age of the patient, the size and number of fibroids and the location of fibroid
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: GnRH agonists: This can be given to women with symptomatic fibroids to reduce the size and also control symptoms. It is also given to women pre-operatively to reduce the size of the fibroid Option B: Laparoscopic hysterectomy: There is no indication for surgical managment in a patient with an asymptomatic fibroid. Following menopause, fibroids usually shrink in size due to hypo-estrogenism. Option C: Laparoscopic myomectomy: There is no indication for doing a myomectomy in a patient with an asymptomatic fibroid.
  • • Option A: GnRH agonists: This can be given to women with symptomatic fibroids to reduce the size and also control symptoms. It is also given to women pre-operatively to reduce the size of the fibroid
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Laparoscopic hysterectomy: There is no indication for surgical managment in a patient with an asymptomatic fibroid. Following menopause, fibroids usually shrink in size due to hypo-estrogenism.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Laparoscopic myomectomy: There is no indication for doing a myomectomy in a patient with an asymptomatic fibroid.
  • • Option C:

questions.text: A 23-year primi is presents at 16 weeks pregnancy with acute abdominal pain. On examination, the uterus is 20 weeks size and there is tenderness over the abdomen. An ultrasound reveals, a 6 cm fibroid in the anterior wall. What is the next best management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Analgesia and hydration

Explanation:

  • • This is most likely a red degeneration of fibroid which is commonly seen in pregnancy. Red degeneration occurs in a large fibroid mainly during 2 nd half of pregnancy and puerperium. Pain is the predominant symptom. Treatment is supportive and pain usually settles with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs
  • • This is most likely a red degeneration of fibroid which is commonly seen in pregnancy.
  • • Red degeneration occurs in a large fibroid mainly during 2 nd half of pregnancy and puerperium.
  • • Pain is the predominant symptom.
  • • Treatment is supportive and pain usually settles with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Advise MTP: This is usually never advised in red degeneration as majority of red degenerations will symotomatically improve Option B: Laparoscopic myomectomy: Not indicated during pregnancy Option C: Hysterotomy and myomectomy: Nor indicated in red degeneration of fibroid
  • • Option A: Advise MTP: This is usually never advised in red degeneration as majority of red degenerations will symotomatically improve
  • • Option B: Laparoscopic myomectomy: Not indicated during pregnancy
  • • Option C: Hysterotomy and myomectomy: Nor indicated in red degeneration of fibroid

questions.text: A 34-year nulliparous woman presents to the OPD. She complains of pelvic heaviness. She also mentions that her periods have been increasingly heavy in amount and she has to take a pain killer on the 1 st 2 days of her period due to excessive pain. The periods are otherwise regular. On examination, there is an irregular mass palpated abdominally which is about the size of an 18 weeks gravid uterus. On bimanual exam, the same irregular mass is felt and there is transmitted mobility. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Leiomyoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This patient has symptoms of heavy menstrual bleed and dysmenorrhea which are seen in adenomyosis, fibroids (leiomyoma) and polyp. On examination, this is a fibroid (probably multiple fibroids) The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses) The woman is nulliparous
  • • This patient has symptoms of heavy menstrual bleed and dysmenorrhea which are seen in adenomyosis, fibroids (leiomyoma) and polyp.
  • • On examination, this is a fibroid (probably multiple fibroids) The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses) The woman is nulliparous
  • • The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses) The woman is nulliparous
  • • The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular
  • • There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses)
  • • The woman is nulliparous
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • In adenomyosis, the uterus is regularly enlarged (max size of 12-14 weeks size) In fibroid polyp, the uterus will be normal or slightly enlarged in size and on speculum exam, a polyp may be seen extruding from the os. Fibroid polyps usually present with inter menstrual bleeding or irregular bleeding In ovarian mass, there usually won't be any menstrual symptoms, also transmitted mobility will be absent (i.e. on moving the mass, the cervix will not be felt to move)
  • • In adenomyosis, the uterus is regularly enlarged (max size of 12-14 weeks size)
  • • In fibroid polyp, the uterus will be normal or slightly enlarged in size and on speculum exam, a polyp may be seen extruding from the os. Fibroid polyps usually present with inter menstrual bleeding or irregular bleeding
  • • In ovarian mass, there usually won't be any menstrual symptoms, also transmitted mobility will be absent (i.e. on moving the mass, the cervix will not be felt to move)

questions.text: A 27-year woman who is anxious to conceive visits the OPD with her husband. They have been trying to conceive for 2 years. She has regular periods with heavy flow. There is associated dysmenorrhea. A transvaginal scan shows a submucosal fibroid of about 2 cm in size. What is the best management option?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Hysteroscopic myomectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient is infertile and has a submucosal fibroid. The fibroid has to be removed. Type 0 and 1 submucosal fibroids are best removed hysteroscopically
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Laparoscopic myomectomy: Is indicated usually in intramural and subserosal fibroids Option B: Reassurance: Whenever an infertile patient has a submucosal fibroid or a large intra-mural fibroid, it has to be removed. Option C: GnRH agonist: Could have been tried if the patient did not have infertility.
  • • Option A: Laparoscopic myomectomy: Is indicated usually in intramural and subserosal fibroids
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Reassurance: Whenever an infertile patient has a submucosal fibroid or a large intra-mural fibroid, it has to be removed.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: GnRH agonist: Could have been tried if the patient did not have infertility.
  • • Option C:

questions.text: A 45-year lady presents with heavy menstrual bleeding for 3 months. On examination, she does not appear to be pale. Her BP is 150/90mmHg. An abdominal and pelvic exam is normal. A transvaginal scan shows a 2 cm Intramural fibroid and an endometrial thickness of 15mm. both the ovaries appear normal What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Endometrial Biopsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • At 45y, heavy bleeding during periods could be because of endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy. It is important to rule out precancerous lesions and cancerous lesions at this age. A small 2 cm fibroid is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms but her increased endometrial thickness on the ultrasound (15 mm is a thick endometrium for her age) could be alikely cause. Th is thickened endometrium warrants an endometrial biopsy to tule out endometrial hyperplasia and cancer
  • • At 45y, heavy bleeding during periods could be because of endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy.
  • • It is important to rule out precancerous lesions and cancerous lesions at this age.
  • • A small 2 cm fibroid is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms but her increased endometrial thickness on the ultrasound (15 mm is a thick endometrium for her age) could be alikely cause.
  • • Th is thickened endometrium warrants an endometrial biopsy to tule out endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fibroids and endometrial hyperplasia/ malignancy usually coexist as both are hyperestrogenic states Women in the peri-menopausal age group with fibroids with heavy menstrual bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial hyperplasia and cancer
  • ➤ Fibroids and endometrial hyperplasia/ malignancy usually coexist as both are hyperestrogenic states
  • ➤ Women in the peri-menopausal age group with fibroids with heavy menstrual bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

questions.text: A 28-year woman comes to the OPD due to discomfort due to urination in the last 3 months. Antibiotics for UTI were prescribed but her symptoms persisted. She has also noted increasing pain with passage of stools for 1 year particularly during menses. Bowel movements occur daily and are soft and not watery. Her symptoms have not improved with decrease in alcohol and caffeine and increased dietary fiber. The patient also has intermittent abdominal pain for 7 months. She is on no medication and has no surgical history. BMI is 19kg/m2. Abdominal exam reveals suprapubic tenderness. On pelvic exam, the uterus is immobile and retroverted. Rectovaginal exam reveals nodularity in the post cul de sac. Urine analysis is normal. Surgical biopsy of the nodules will most likely show?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Endometrial glands and stroma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is endometriosis which is ectopic endometrium hence the histopathology of the nodules will show endometrial glands and stroma. Clues in this clinical question which point towards endometriosis are: Complaints of painful defecation Abdominal pain Nodularity in the POD

questions.text: With endometriosis, as shown here, which of the following is ectopically located?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: Which of the following theories is the most widely accepted as the cause of endometriosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Retrograde menstruation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The definitive cause of endometriosis remains unknown, but theories have been proposed.
  • • Retrograde menstruation through the fallopian tubes: Most favored theory
  • • Retrograde menstruation through the fallopian tubes: Most favored theory
  • • All the other options are less favoured theories. These include:
  • • All the other options are less favoured theories. These include:
  • • The stem cell theory: implicates undifferentiated endometrial cells that initially reside in the endometrium’s basalis layer. These cells differentiate into epithelial, stromal, and vascular cells as the endometrium is routinely regenerated each cycle. If displaced to an ectopic location, such as by retrograde menstruation, these stem cells may give rise to endometriosis Aberrant lymphatic or vascular spread of endometrial tissue has also been implicated. Coelomic metaplasia and suggests that the parietal peritoneum is pluripotent and can undergo metaplastic transformation to tissue histologically identical to normal endometrium.
  • • The stem cell theory: implicates undifferentiated endometrial cells that initially reside in the endometrium’s basalis layer. These cells differentiate into epithelial, stromal, and vascular cells as the endometrium is routinely regenerated each cycle. If displaced to an ectopic location, such as by retrograde menstruation, these stem cells may give rise to endometriosis
  • • Aberrant lymphatic or vascular spread of endometrial tissue has also been implicated.
  • • Coelomic metaplasia and suggests that the parietal peritoneum is pluripotent and can undergo metaplastic transformation to tissue histologically identical to normal endometrium.

questions.text: Persistence of endometriosis is directly dependent on which of the following hormones?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Estrogen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Endometriosis is a hyperestrogenic state

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endometriosis is a Hyperestrogenic state. Estrogen facilitates the growth of the ectopic endometrial glands. Endometriosis is an estrogen-dependent, chronic inflammatory disease with aberrant growth of ectopic endometrial tissue. The disturbed molecular mechanisms in this disease are yet to be completely defined. However, suspected underpinnings include an environment estrogen dominance, estrogen dependence, and progesterone resistance within implants; inflammation; escape from immune clearance; local invasion and neurovascular development; and genetic predisposition.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the most part, endometriosis is a disease confined to the pelvis. Signs may not be present in all patients on examination During bimanual examination, pelvic organ palpation often reveals suggestive anatomic abnormalities. Uterosacral ligament nodularity and tenderness may reflect active disease or scarring along the ligament. An enlarged, cystic adnexal mass may represent an ovarian endometrioma, which can be mobile or adhered to other pelvic structures. A retroverted, fixed, tender uterus and a firm, fixed posterior cul-de-sac are among other findings. Pelvic nodularity secondary to endometriosis may be more easily detected by bimanual examination during menses Rectal examination may reveal rectovaginal septum nodularity or tenderness Rarely, blue or red powder burn lesions are seen on the cervix or the posterior vaginal fornix. These lesions can be tender or bleed with contact.

questions.text: Which of the following methods can reliably assist in making the diagnosis of endometriosis?
questions.explanation:

Implants are typically round on pelvic organ serosa and pelvic peritoneum. Lesions are variably colored and can be red (red, red-pink, or clear), white (white or yellow-brown), and black (black or black-blue) White and red lesions most commonly correlate with the characteristic histologic findings of endometriosis Dark lesions are pigmented by hemosiderin deposition rom trapped menstrual debris. In addition to color differences, endometriotic lesions may differ morphologically. They can appear as smooth blebs on peritoneal surfaces, as holes or defects within the peritoneum, or as flat stellate lesions whose points are formed by surrounding scar tissue. Endometriotic lesions may be superficial or may deeply invade the peritoneum or pelvic organs. Endometriomas are easily identified during laparoscopy.

questions.text: Women seeking immediate fertility and who suffer from endometriosis would most likely benefit from which of the following treatments?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Laparoscopic ablation of lesions

Explanation:

  • • Treatment of endometriosis is by both medical or surgical management If pain is prominent and conception is not currently desired, then medical therapy is typically selected. Available agents include NSAIDs, OCPs, progestins, GnRH agents, and aromatase inhibitors. In general, suitable starting regimens are NSAIDS alone or combined with oral contraceptive pills or with a progestin. Although medical treatment improves pain, relapse rates are high with therapy discontinuation. If infertility is the presenting symptom, then laparoscopic management should be considered (ablation/ excision of endometriotic implants)

questions.text: For surgical treatment of endometriomas, which of the following approaches is superior?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Cystectomy

Explanation:

  • • Endometriomas are typically treated surgically to exclude malignancy or treat associated pain. Cystectomy lowers endometrioma recurrence rates and pain symptoms and improves subsequent spontaneous pregnancy rates During surgery, ideally normal ovarian tissue is preserved as much as possible

questions.text: A 20-year-old nulligravida with a last menstrual period 5 days ago presents to the emergency department with generalized lower abdominal pain and fever. She reports a new sexual partner. Physical examination demonstrates guarding and bilateral adnexal fullness. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis, and transvaginal sonography reveals no visible ovaries, but bilateral adnexal masses as shown here. The diagnosis most consistent with these findings is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Tuboovarian abscess

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is a tubo-ovarian abscess which is seen in Pelvic Inflammatory Disease It is an inflammatory mass involving the fallopian tube, ovary, and often surrounding structures. If an ovary adheres to the fallopian tube, but is still visualized, it is called a tubo-ovarian complex. A tuboovarian abscess results from a complete breakdown ovarian and tubal architecture such that the separate structures are no longer identified. Affected women usually have lower abdominal pain, fever, leukocytosis, and unilateral or bilateral adnexal masses. Initial treatment of a tubo-ovarian abscess is by In patient antibiotic treatment If no response to medical management observed, surgical management is considered

  • • It is an inflammatory mass involving the fallopian tube, ovary, and often surrounding structures.
  • • If an ovary adheres to the fallopian tube, but is still visualized, it is called a tubo-ovarian complex.
  • • A tuboovarian abscess results from a complete breakdown ovarian and tubal architecture such that the separate structures are no longer identified.

  • • Initial treatment of a tubo-ovarian abscess is by In patient antibiotic treatment
  • • If no response to medical management observed, surgical management is considered
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Endometriosis: This commonly presents as dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dull aching abdominal pain and infertility. Examination will reveal a retroverted fixed uterus and nodularoty may be present. An ultrasound will show a chocolate cyst Option B: Ovarian torsion will present as acute abdominal pain and this will increase and not be relieved by medication. A Doppler best diagnosis this condition where the classical whirlpool sign will be seen Option D: Malignant ovarian neoplasm: This usually presents in the older age group with GI symptoms. Ultrasound will show a complex ovarian mass with solid areas, papillary projections, ascites and metastases

  • • Option B: Ovarian torsion will present as acute abdominal pain and this will increase and not be relieved by medication. A Doppler best diagnosis this condition where the classical whirlpool sign will be seen
  • • Option D: Malignant ovarian neoplasm: This usually presents in the older age group with GI symptoms. Ultrasound will show a complex ovarian mass with solid areas, papillary projections, ascites and metastases

questions.text: A 32-year woman presents with acute abdominal pain & vomiting. On examination, there is abdominal tenderness. Ultrasound shows an ovarian cyst. Laparoscopic image is shown. Which is incorrect?

Ans. D. USG Doppler is not a useful test in diagnosing torsion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation

  • • Let us discuss all the options:
  • • Let us discuss all the options:
  • • Option A: Ovarian dermoid are commonly associated with this: Ovarian dermoids are commonly associated with torsion. As they are light in weight due to sebaceous material, they easily undergo torsion Option B: The ovary can undergo infarction if surgery is delayed: If the surgery is delayed, the vascular supply to the ovary is cut off and this can cause necrosis of the ovary Option C: Detorsion and ovarian cystectomy should be done: Laparoscopic detorsion and ovarian cystectomy is the preferred method of treatment. However on detorsion, if the color (vascularity) does not return, then ovariectomy may have to be done. Option D: USG Doppler is not a useful test in diagnosing torsion: This is incorrect as USG + Doppler is the investigation of choice for diagnosing ovarian torsion

  • ➤ Adnexal Torsion
  • ➤ Adnexal Torsion
  • ➤ Torsion involves the twisting of adnexal components. Most often, the ovary and fallopian tube rotate as a single entity. Infrequently, an ovary may alone turn about its mesovarium, and rarely a fallopian tube twists alone about the mesosalpinx. Most commonly occurs during the reproductive years Common in pregnancy. Risk Factors Adnexal masses with increased mobility Excessively mobile mesovaria or fallopian tubes and may increase the risk in even normal adnexa. Pathologically enlarged ovaries with a diameter > 6 cm (Rt ovary more common) Dermoid cysts are light and tend to undergo torsion easily C/F Classically, the woman with adnexal torsion complains of sharp lower abdominal pain with sudden onset that worsens intermittently over several hours. The pain usually is localized to the involved side, with radiation to the aflnk, groin, or thigh. Low-grade fever suggests adnexal necrosis. Nausea and vomiting frequently accompany the pain. Adnexal mass may not be palpable. Diagnosis Ultrasound D/D: Ectopic pregnancy, tuboovarian abscess, hemorrhagic ovarian cyst, and endometrioma. The twisted pedicle may also appear as a bull’s-eye target, whirlpool, or snail shell, that is, a rounded hyperechoic structure with multiple, inner, concentric hypoechoic rings. Transvaginal color Doppler sonography may show disruption of normal adnexal blood ow. disruption Management Laparoscopy and detorsion: Management of choice If ovarian cyst: Cystectomy can be done at same or separate sitting If no return to vascularity: Can consider adnexectomy/ ovariectomy To minimize recurrence: unilateral or bilateral oophoropexy

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman undergoes a total hysterectomy for painful fibroids. The ovaries will not be removed during the procedure. Which of the following ligaments must be preserved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Infundibulopelvic  ligament

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The ovaries are held in place by the ovarian ligaments medially (attach ovary to the uterus) and the infundibulopelvic ligaments laterally (attach the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall) In a hysterectomy if the ovaries are to be preserved, the ovarian ligament is clamped, cut and ligated (i.e. infundibulopelvic ligament is preserved) In a hysterectomy, if the ovaries are to be removed, the infundibulopelvic ligament is clamped, cut and ligated. Hence to preseve the ovaries, the Infundibulopelvic ligament needs to be preserved
  • • The ovaries are held in place by the ovarian ligaments medially (attach ovary to the uterus) and the infundibulopelvic ligaments laterally (attach the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall)
  • • In a hysterectomy if the ovaries are to be preserved, the ovarian ligament is clamped, cut and ligated (i.e. infundibulopelvic ligament is preserved)
  • • In a hysterectomy, if the ovaries are to be removed, the infundibulopelvic ligament is clamped, cut and ligated.
  • • Hence to preseve the ovaries, the Infundibulopelvic ligament needs to be preserved
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B: Ovarian ligament : When the ovary needs to be preseved, the ovarian ligament is CUT, not preserved Option C: Uterosacral ligaments: These are ligaments that support the uterus posteriorly and are not related to the ovaries Option D: Transverse cervical ligaments: These provide lateral supports to the uterus
  • • Option B: Ovarian ligament : When the ovary needs to be preseved, the ovarian ligament is CUT, not preserved
  • • Option B: Ovarian ligament
  • • Option C: Uterosacral ligaments: These are ligaments that support the uterus posteriorly and are not related to the ovaries
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Transverse cervical ligaments: These provide lateral supports to the uterus
  • • Option D:

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient at 12 weeks presents to the emergency department with complaints of pelvic pain. Transabdominal sonography reveals these bilateral multilocular cystic ovarian masses as shown in the image. Which of the following commonly associated conditions must be excluded in pregnancies with this finding? A. Fetal hydrops B. Gestational trophoblastic disease C. Gestational Diabetes D. Macrosomia E. Multifetal gestation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 1,2,5

Explanation:

  • • This image is showing theca lutein cysts. These are an uncommon type of follicular cyst, characterized by luteinization and hypertrophy of their theca interna layer. Bilateral, multiple smooth-walled cysts form and range in size from 1 to 4 cm in diameter. Also called Hyperreactio lutealis Due to elevated LH or β-hCG levels. Commonly associated conditions include Gestational trophoblastic disease Multiple pregnancy Placentomegaly (As is seen in fetal hydrops, syphilis etc) Ovarian hyperstimulation during assisted reproductive techniques These cysts typically resolve spontaneously following removal o the stimulating hormone source. These are prone to ovarian torsion

questions.text: The USG finding of “tip of the iceberg” sign corresponds to the site within a mature cystic teratoma where the most varied tissue types, such as hair and fatty secretions, are found. Pathologically, what is this area called?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Rokitansky protuberance

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are benign tumors comprising 10 to 25 percent of all ovarian neoplasms and 60 percent of all benign ovarian neoplasms These cystic tumors are typically slow growing, and most measure between 5 and 10 cm They are bilateral in approximately 10 percent When sectioned, most cysts appear unilocular and typically contain one area of localized growth, which protrudes into the cystic cavity. Alternatively designated as Rokitansky protuberance, dermoid plug, dermoid process, dermoid mamilla, or embryonal rudiment, this protuberance can be absent or multiple.

Alternatively designated as Rokitansky protuberance, dermoid plug, dermoid process, dermoid mamilla, or embryonal rudiment, this protuberance can be absent or multiple.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Homunculus: Very rarely, a dermoid may contain a fetal like structure called homunculus Option B: Struma ovarii: This is used to describe an ovarian dermoid containing primarily thyroid tissue Option C: Hydatid of Morgagni: Hydatids of Morgagni are benign, pedunculated, cystic structures arising from müllerian vestiges below the fallopian tube near the fimbria

questions.text: A 26-year G2P1 at 16 weeks pregnancy, presents to the emergency department with complaints of worsening right pelvic pain. She states that she had the sudden onset of sharp pain after bending. She experienced intense nausea with the pain. The pain did not respond to analgesics at home and has in fact worsened. On examination, the uterus is 16 weeks, and she has guarding. An ultrasound reveals a single live pregnancy of 16 weeks with an 8cm enlarged right ovary with high impedance arterial flow of the ovary on color Doppler. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Laparoscopy with detorsion of the ovary

questions.correct_answer: C. Laparoscopy with detorsion of the ovary
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Laparoscopy with detorsion of the ovary

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is pregnancy with ovarian torsion Ovarian torsion is common in pregnancy and is managed in a similar way As the patient is in the 2 nd trimester, the best management option would be a laparoscopy and attempt at detorsion of the ovary. Laparoscopy is safe in the 2 nd trimester.
  • • This is pregnancy with ovarian torsion
  • • Ovarian torsion is common in pregnancy and is managed in a similar way
  • • As the patient is in the 2 nd trimester, the best management option would be a laparoscopy and attempt at detorsion of the ovary.
  • • Laparoscopy is safe in the 2 nd trimester.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: General surgery consultation: As the diagnosis of ovarian torsion is highly likely, a surgery consult is not required Option B: Laparoscopy with adnexectomy: Adnexectomy means removing the adnexa (ovary and fallopian tube): This may have to be done in case on detorsion, vacularity does not return. However the management of choice is a laparoscopy and ovarian detorsion Option D: Observe: As the patient is in severe pain and there is torsion, immediate surgery is essential else the ovary can undergo necrosis and due to release of inflammatory markers, the pregnancy can also be affected (increased risk of abortion)
  • • Option A: General surgery consultation: As the diagnosis of ovarian torsion is highly likely, a surgery consult is not required
  • • Option A:

  • • Option B:
  • • Option D: Observe: As the patient is in severe pain and there is torsion, immediate surgery is essential else the ovary can undergo necrosis and due to release of inflammatory markers, the pregnancy can also be affected (increased risk of abortion)
  • • Option D:

questions.text: 25-year nulliparous woman with history of an ectopic pregnancy presents with subfertility with subfertility of 2 y. She complains of recurrent vaginal discharge. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals the following. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hydrosalpinx

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The above scenario is that of a hydrosalpinx. Points in favor of this are:
  • • H/o ectopic pregnancy H/o subfertility Recurrent discharge PV USG showing a retort shaped hypoechoic collection suggestive of hydrosalpinx

It may be bilateral and there may be associated ascites/ metastases. Option B: Endometriosis: This will present as dysmenorrhoea, dyschezia, dyspareunia. Though infertility is seen in endometriosis, on ultrasound a ground glass ovarian cyst will be seen (Chocolate cyst) Option D: Broad ligament fibroid: This could be asymptomatic. It could also present as abdominal mass or abnormal uterine bleeding

questions.text: Which of the following vulvar dermatoses commonly presents with oral lesions, such as the one shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Lichen Planus

Explanation:

  • • Lichen planus is an uncommon disease involves both cutaneous and mucosal surfaces and affects genders equally between ages 30 and 60 years Women typically complain of chronic vaginal discharge with intense vulvovaginal pruritus, burning pain, dyspareunia, and postcoital bleeding. On inspection, papules classically are brightly erythematous or violaceous, flat topped, shiny polygons most commonly round on the trunk, buccal mucosa, or flexor sur aces of the extremities Lacy, white striations (Wickham striae) are frequently found in conjunction with the papules and may also be present on the buccal mucosa Deep, painful erosions in the posterior vestibule can extend to the labia, resulting in agglutination. With speculum insertion, vulvar skin and vaginal mucosa bleed easily. Vaginal erosions can produce adhesions and synechiae, which may lead to vaginal obliteration. Women with suspected lichen planus require a thorough dermatologic survey looking or extragenital lesions. Nearly one quarter of women with oral lesions will have vulvovaginal involvement, and most with erosive vulvovaginal lichen planus will have oral involvement. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy. Treatment: Erosive vulvar lichen planus is treated initially with ultrapotent topical corticosteroid ointments, such as 0.05-percent clobetasol propionate applied daily or up to 3 months, and then slowly tapered

questions.text: Treatment of vaginal lichen planus is challenging, and symptomatic relief has been reported using which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Vaginal corticosteroid suppositories

Explanation:

  • • Suppositories containing 25 mg of hydrocortisone used vaginally are helpful Combining local corticosteroid therapy with vaginal dilator use may help restore coital function in patients with moderate vaginal synechiae. If topical medications fail, systemic treatment with prednisone 40 to 60 mg daily or up to 4 weeks may modulate symptoms

questions.text: An 18-year girl presents with a painful enlarged Bartholin cyst. She is a 1 st year medical student and is curious as to how this developed. Bartholin gland duct cysts form in direct response to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Gland duct obstruction

Explanation:

  • • Mucus produced to lubricate the vulva originates in part from the Bartholin glands. Obstruction of this gland’s duct is common and may follow infection, trauma, mucus changes, or congenitally narrowed ducts. In some cases, cyst contents may become infected and lead to abscess formation. Escherichia coli is the most common isolate, but various other gram-positive and gram-negative aerobes and anaerobes are found Infrequently, Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis is identified
  • • Mucus produced to lubricate the vulva originates in part from the Bartholin glands.

questions.text: The image below best represents which of the following vulvar disorders?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Bartholin gland duct cyst

Explanation:

  • • This is a Bartholin gland duct cyst Most Bartholin gland cysts are small and asymptomatic except or minor discom ort during sexual contact. With larger or infected cysts, however, patients may complain of severe vulvar pain that precludes walking, sitting, or sexual activity On physical examination, cysts typically are unilateral, round or ovoid, and fluctuant or tense. I If infected, they display surrounding erythema and are tender. The mass is usually located in the inferior labia majora or lower vestibule. Whereas most cysts and abscesses lead to labial asymmetry, smaller cysts may be detected only by palpation. Small, asymptomatic Bartholin gland duct cysts require no intervention except exclusion of neoplasia in women older than 40 years. However, a symptomatic cyst may be managed with one of several techniques. These include: Incision and drainage (I&D) Marsupialization Bartholin gland excision

questions.text: According to the October 2003 ISSVD World Congress, which of the following terms most often describes burning vulvar pain occurring in the absence of relevant visible findings or specific, clinically identifiable disorders?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Vulvodynia

Explanation:

  • • In 2003, the ISSVD defined vulvodynia as “vulvar discomfort, most often described as burning pain, occurring in the absence of relevant visible findings or a specific, clinically identifiable, neurologic disorder” The term vestibulitis was eliminated from ISSVD terminology since inflammatory changes have not been consistently documented. Vulvar pain is described as spontaneous (unprovoked), triggered by physical pressure (provoked), or mixed. Vulvar pain described by most patients as burning, stinging, or a raw irritation is further categorized as localized or generalized

questions.text: A 33-year woman presents to the OPD. She complains of difficulty in inserting a tampon and says she feels something in the vagina. O/e, a vaginal swelling is seen arising from the anterolateral vaginal wall as shown. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Gartner duct cyst

Explanation:

  • • Most vaginal cysts are epidermoid cysts, urethral diverticula, or Gartner duct cysts. Gartner duct cysts develop from mesonephric (wolffian) duct remnants. They are typically asymptomatic and found within the lateral vaginal wall during routine examination. C/F: Dyspareunia, vaginal pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination reveals a tense cyst that is palpable or seen to bulge from beneath the vaginal wall. Observation is reasonable in most cases, although marsupialization or excision may be appropriate or symptomatic Gartner duct cysts.

questions.text: All EXCEPT which of the following are appropriate medical treatments for adenomyosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Copper intrauterine device

Explanation:

  • • Adenomyosis can be managed medically NSAIDs Anti-fibrinolytics Combined OCPS LNG-IUS SPRMs Surgical (Hysterectomy) is the definitive treatment of adenomyosis A copper containing IUCD will increase the bleeding and should not be used for adenomyosis
